The essence of programming is composition. In the OOP paradigm we are building sofware by using Object that communicates with each other. To build bigger software we compose those objects. The object is the building block

In FP the building block is a function! Each function operates on data. The software is made using functions and we compose them to build bigger software.

What is functional programming? what are those principle? Gonna talk here about the very basics of FP using the functional language OCaml

Pure function

  1. Its result depends only on its input‚Äîand not on any external state
  2. It has no side effects such as mutating a global state/reference arguments, having I/O‚Ä¶

Pure functions are so easy to test and predictables. I believe in a program one want to maximize pure functions and push unpure code at the edge.

Gives us the ability to memoize the function

Immutability

An immutable variable means its value can‚Äôt be changed after it‚Äôs created. If you want to modify it, well you don‚Äôt. Instead you create a new variable with the new value.

In OCaml record fields are immutable by default.

let me = {
  first_name = "Vincent";
  last_name  = "Cordobes";
  age        = 25;
}

If you try to update me, you‚Äôll get an error

me.age <- 35 (* The record field age is not mutable *)

Instead you need to create a new variable

let new_me = { me with age = 35 }

In some other languages objects are mutables by default which can lead to many ‚Äúwtf!‚Äù
For example in javascript:

const me = { name: 'Vince', age: 23 }
console.log(me.age) // 23
sayAge(me)
console.log(me.age) // 498
ü§î ??

Who is responsible for that age change? It must be printAge! It‚Äôs the only function call we made between the two console.log. But wait‚Ä¶ can we really trust console.log ? What if I tell you it‚Äôs been monkey patched? replaced by a custom bugged logger üôà Okay chances are low but if one is being imaginative, it‚Äôs possible. The point is that in a mutable world we can‚Äôt really trust anything. As you can see even in a 4 lines program, mutability can lead to very unexpected behaviour.

So immutability guaranties us that a variable will never change. It‚Äôs not an FP specific thing but generally seen as a best practice as it makes odes more readable and maintainable. It also makes it easier to do concurrent programming, eliminates defensive copies etc..

Is mutability always bad tho? Of couse not and as often in IT, it depends! If it‚Äôs local, well controlled, makes it more convenient or allow us to optimize a performance critical part of the program it‚Äôs totally OK.

Referential transparency

Referential transparency means you can replace an expresssion by its value without changing the program behaviour.
